I, too, was lucky enough to get a first-rate education and I devoted much of it reading wonderful writers like Faulkner and the rest. I still read voraciously, but when I want to really escape into a novel, nothing beats "genre fiction". I have high standards for the noir, fantasy, and science fiction I read, but when I find a real gem my mood lifts until I finish it. The best of these kinds of books can be just as challenging, surprising, and complex as anything I've read.

I thank the many writers like Mr. Grossman who write quality fiction that is also intensely absorbing. Too much of today's bestselling "literature" is simply boring.

While I agree that the teacher should not be telling students what her priorities should be, I think kids need to learn that having priorities means making sacrifices. Asking a teacher to extend a deadline due to a sporting event is telling the teacher that sports is more important than the assignment. That being the case, the student should accept that he or she may get a lower score by turning in a late or less polished assignment than she might if she prioritized academics over sports. Better to learn in school that you can't give 100% to every task and/or expect others to accommodate your priorities all the time than to be an adult thinking that you can do it all--career, family, recreation--without having occasionally to choose one.

It can be done! The Giants recently played a game in 2:06, and were almost as efficient the following day However, today's game ran 3:34, even without any of those painfully slow NYC reviews. While it was an exciting game, but only the beer vendors want games to last that long.

Some pitchers like Tim Lincecum and Jon Lester routinely deliver successive pitches within the 12 second official limit, while the umps let relievers in tight situations stall and fidget for 30 seconds or more. It's well-known that fielders are less alert when the game drags.

Let's make the batter stay in the box after any pitch where he doesn't make contact. No more of this Nomar-inspired redoing of the velcro after each pitch, even when they just "took" the pitch. Umpires should be able to award balls and strikes for delay of the game, and networks showing games should be prevented from adding commercials that extend the break between half-innings beyond the official 2 minutes and 15 seconds. Maybe we'll only get an average of 10 minutes back, but that's more than 25 hours over a season. More significantly, though, we can stop young players from adopting the delaying habit that have become so prevalent now.

i lived at Connie Mack Stadium also in 1970 and went to 70 games with my father who was an usher. Phillies averaged about 10,000 per game and were still talking about '64.  Saw Buning and Short vs Koufax and Drysdale in a twilight double header.  No separate admission for each game. Price of my ticket $1.50 for a good seat 1st floor near 3rd base.  In 1970, pitchers pitched 9 innings and started every 4th game.  Batters hit against righties and lefties. Knock down pitches didn't clear the benches. Games under 2 hrs were common.  What's different now? TV commercials.  The longer the game, like other sports, the more commercials = the more $$$ until ratings drop significantly.  And the internet, people don't have the attention span anymore for 3 hrs not on their computer or smartphone.

I always record the my team, the NY Mets,  as I am usually not available when the games are played.  I realize that due to the slowness of the game I have to add the 3 hour extension for each game.  I'm glad I do because the 3 hour projected actual time of the game always runs beyond the time.  I think the most necessary time for me to add the 3 hour extension in recording the game was when Mike Pelfrey pitched for the Mets.  I was always prepared to be up beyond midnight.  It always pained me to watch him.  In fact when he pitched I could get up, go to the john, prepare a snack and he would still be on the mound when I returned!
